claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination broadens tumor antigen presentation, including MHC-I peptide display.

evidence.quote: Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination
Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination induces a type I interferon-rich tumor state linked to sensitization.

evidence.quote: Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors, limiting direct clinical extrapolation.

claims.claim: The combination rationale is supported by increased PD-L1 axis activity and improved mouse tumor control context.

evidence.quote: PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable
Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: Vaccine-only and ICI-only arms showed limited durability/activity in some settings, so benefit depends on context and combination design.

claims.claim: Prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination is associated with better survival among metastatic patients treated with ICI.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment
The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

claims.caveat: Because patient groups were non-randomized and clinically heterogeneous, this association should not be interpreted as definitive causality.
